All Rights Reserved.</rights><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml" href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/AtlanticNational" /><feedburner:info uri="atlanticnational" /><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="hub" href="http://pubsubhubbub.appspot.com/" /><entry><content type="html"><p>What does the dissenting mail look like, when I publish <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/deeply-saddened/553478/?utm_source=feed">an item like this one</a>, arguing that Mitch McConnell illustrates the pious hypocrisy of those who are “deeply saddened” by gun massacres but obstruct efforts to prevent them, or round-ups of reader responses like <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2017/11/why-the-ar-15-was-never-meant-to-be-in-civilians-hands/545438/?utm_source=feed">this</a>?</p><p>Here is a representative sample.</p><p><em>Draconian controls</em>. I said in my McConnell item that the NRA had successfully equated <em>any</em> proposed control on gun use and ownership with <em>total</em> control. (We recognize that DUI laws and liability-insurance requirements don’t amount to confiscation of your car, but that distinction disappears when we’re talking about guns.) One dissenting note illustrates this outlook:</p><blockquote>
<p>Sorry, but I'm guessing you'll favor draconian gun laws no matter what the crime rate or frequecy of mass killings. I also suspect that you'll carry water for the anti-gun Left no matter what, and that you'll keep ginning up facts to supoport that cultural/ideological project.</p>

<p>I'm sure that you and your fellow East Coast journalist colleagues will cover for Feinstein, Schumer, Pelosi, and company when federal  agents kill some innocent people in the course of enforcing the gun laws you favor the way you did back in the early '90s.  Will you have "blood on your hands" then?</p>

<p>Frankly, I'm sorry I ever got into the habit of looking at Atlantic Online. I suppose I assumed it was the same publication that Michael Kelley edited years ago. I won't do it again, though.</p>
</blockquote><p>Similarly:</p><blockquote>
<p>Could you provide an example of where the proposed controls have worked? I believe this is a fair and reasonable question to ask.</p>

<p>We have background checks last I looked.</p>

<p>And if you ban a weapon like the demonized AR15...who pays for the rifles as they are turned in? Do you really believe they will all be turned in even if you could get it passed?</p>

<p>This knee-jerk reaction every time this happens, pretending that gun control is the answer without any evidence is not helpful.</p>

<p>Would you favor the death penalty for anyone possessing an unlawful firearm?</p>

<p>Again, I think these are fair questions you left unanswered in your article.</p>
</blockquote><p>For an example of where proposed controls have made a difference, I would offer: the entire rest of the world. All developed countries contain mentally ill people. <em>Only in the United States</em> do these people <em>repeatedly</em> engage in large-scale slaughter with guns. Only in the United States do significant numbers of people argue that policies or controls could not possibly make a difference.  </p> <p><a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2018/02/readers-opposing-more-gun-control-efforts/553622/?utm_source=feed">Read On &raquo;</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/8mTZGVGcuUY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>James Fallows</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/james-fallows/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2018/02/RTX4XD17_1/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Jonathan Drake / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">Only in America</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/8mTZGVGcuUY/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-17T10:00:00-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-17T12:23:44-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:374-553622</id><summary type="html">What does the dissenting mail look like, when I publish <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/deeply-saddened/553478/">an item like this one</a>, arguing that Mitch McConnell illustrates…</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2018/02/readers-opposing-more-gun-control-efforts/553622/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>After a previous horrific massacre via AR-15, the one in Las Vegas last winter in which a single murderer killed or injured <em>more than 900</em> people<i>, </i>readers wrote about that weapon and its history. For reference, those items were:</p><ul><li>“<a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/11/why-the-ar-15-is-so-lethal/545162/?utm_source=feed">Why the AR-15 Is So Lethal</a>”</li>
	<li>“<a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2017/11/the-nature-of-the-ar-15/545414/?utm_source=feed">The Nature of the AR-15</a>”</li>
	<li>“<a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2017/11/why-the-ar-15-was-never-meant-to-be-in-civilians-hands/545438/?utm_source=feed">Why the AR-15 Was Never Meant to be in Civilian Hands</a>”</li>
	<li>“<a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2017/11/on-the-military-and-civilian-history-of-the-ar-15/545660/?utm_source=feed">More on the Military and Civilian History of the AR-15</a>”</li>
</ul><p>Now we have another massacre; more “thoughts and prayers” and other <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/deeply-saddened/553478/?utm_source=feed">pious but empty rituals</a> by legislators who will not do a single thing to reduce the chances of the next one; and more reaction from readers.</p><p>Can <em>anything</em> be done, by anyone or any organization, to stop the onslaught of gun violence? Readers suggest three approaches, involving: the media, the responsible gun-owning community, and the political opposition to the NRA.</p><p><strong>Different media coverage</strong>. I mentioned yesterday the familiar cycles of news coverage: 24/7 updates, panels, and interviews by cable programs; explanatory pieces by big newspapers; snapshot photos showing victims when they were alive and happy, then respectful portraits of their families wracked by grief. What could be a different approach?</p><p><em>“Show Us the Carnage.” </em>A reader, writing in after a different massacre, says that coverage is too respectful and tasteful:</p><blockquote>
<p>The media needs to show Americans the truth.  Watching tonight's news coverage of the massacre, it was bizarrely possible to think of a mass shooting as a random event like a tornado that causes a community to rally together.  Thoughts and prayers for all.  Yet entirely missing from the coverage was the truth of what had happened.  No pictures of pools of blood.  No video of blown out brains.  No images of dead children in pews.</p>

<p>Just as the tide of public opinion against the war in Vietnam did not turn until images of the war reached into American living rooms, today's epidemic of mass shootings will not end until Americans see and share in the bloody experience.  Scalia's <i>Heller</i> decision will not join Taney's <i>Dred Scott</i> opinion in the ash heap of history until Americans are moved to action by indelible images from mass shootings of suffering and death.</p>

<p>So here is a plea to the media. Do not let decency standards shield us from this indecency.  Show us the carnage and do not let Americans look away from what the NRA's lobbying has wrought.</p>
</blockquote><p>This reader is right, that photos made a difference in the Vietnam era. The recent Ken Burns / Lynn Novick <em>Vietnam</em> documentary series went into the detailed background of the two photos that ran on the front pages of most newspapers, and that anyone alive in that era can recall. One was of a <a href="http://time.com/4485344/napalm-girl-war-photo-facebook/">nine-year-old girl</a> running naked, and in terror, away from a napalm strike. The other was of a South Vietnamese general <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2018/02/01/a-grisly-photo-of-a-saigon-execution-50-years-ago-shocked-the-world-and-helped-end-the-war/">blowing out the brains</a> (literally) of a North Vietnamese agent / spy. A decade earlier, the photo of the battered body of the <a href="http://time.com/4399793/emmett-till-civil-rights-photography/">lynched Emmett Till</a> also revealed what had happened to him in a way mere words could not have done. And lest we forget: the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/look-at-the-picture/2018/02/07/edceaae4-0c59-11e8-8890-372e2047c935_story.html">black-eye photo</a> of one of Rob Porter’s ex-wives,  Colbie Holderness.</p> <p><a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2018/02/show-us-the-carnage-and-other-changes-to-the-post-massacre-ritual/553607/?utm_source=feed">Read On &raquo;</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/MQXnXV35YU0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>James Fallows</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/james-fallows/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2018/02/RTX4XCZ6/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">'Show Us the Carnage' </title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/MQXnXV35YU0/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-17T09:00:00-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-17T15:21:44-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:374-553607</id><summary type="html">After a previous horrific massacre via AR-15, the one in Las Vegas last winter in which a single murderer killed…</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2018/02/show-us-the-carnage-and-other-changes-to-the-post-massacre-ritual/553607/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p dir="ltr">A wealth of details was recorded about the day Frederick Douglass died as a free man in Washington, D.C. It was February 20, 1895. Douglass’s movements in the hours before his death were laid out in the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/bday/0207.html"><em>New York Times </em>obituary</a> published the following day: He spent the morning at the Congressional library, then traveled to Metzerott Hall for sessions of the National Council of Women of the United States, staying through the afternoon; in the early evening he returned home, had dinner with his wife, and was standing and talking to her about the Women’s Council when, suddenly, he had a heart attack and “dropped dead in the hallway” at 7 p.m.</p><p dir="ltr">Comparatively, little is known about the day Douglass was born into slavery in Maryland as Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey. Douglass himself was never even able to pinpoint exactly which day it was. His first autobiography, <em>Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass</em>, begins not with his birthday but with its aching absence:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">I was born in Tuckahoe, near Hillsborough, and about 12 miles from Easton, in Talbot county, Maryland. I have no accurate knowledge of my age, never having seen any authentic record containing it. By far the larger part of the slaves know as little of their ages as horses know of theirs, and it is the wish of most masters within my knowledge to keep their slaves thus ignorant. I do not remember to have ever met a slave who could tell of his birthday. They seldom come nearer to it than planting-time, harvest-time, cherry-time, spring-time, or fall-time. A want of information concerning my own was a source of unhappiness to me even during childhood. The white children could tell their ages. I could not tell why I ought to be deprived of the same privilege. I was not allowed to make any inquiries of my master concerning it. He deemed all such inquiries on the part of a slave improper and impertinent, and evidence of a restless spirit.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">After Douglass escaped bondage and fled north in 1838, he took on a new surname and eventually, though the exact date continued to elude him, chose to celebrate his birthday annually on February 14. As the year of his birth was recorded as 1818, that means February 14, 2018 marked the 200th anniversary of his adopted birth date.</p><p dir="ltr">Fortunately, the extraordinary moments and measures of his life were also well-recorded in the 1895 <em>Times</em> obituary and across thousands of other pages, many produced by Douglass himself. Though his slave master and mistress tried to prevent him from learning to read and write as a child, Douglass was able to find teachers among the poor local white boys and glean further lessons from his surroundings, and after gaining his freedom he became a powerful voice for emancipation and equal rights by way of his writing. In the decades leading up to the Civil War, he toured the country giving speeches against slavery, wrote two memoirs-cum-abolitionist tracts, and published the anti-slavery newspaper <em>The North Star</em>. Shortly after the war’s conclusion, he wrote two articles for <em>The Atlantic</em>, eloquently advocating for the elevation and protection of individual rights under the law to prevent further oppression and abuse.</p><p dir="ltr">In the first of these articles, published in our December 1866 issue, Douglass considered <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1866/12/reconstruction/304561/?utm_source=feed">how Reconstruction could and should reform the South</a>. “In reconstructing the institutions of these shattered and overthrown States, Congress should begin with a clean slate, and make clean work of it,” he wrote:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">Let there be no hesitation. It would be a cowardly deference to a defeated and treacherous President, if any account were made of the illegitimate, one-sided, sham governments hurried into existence for a malign purpose in the absence of Congress. These pretended governments, which were never submitted to the people, and from participation in which four millions of the loyal people were excluded by Presidential order, should now be treated according to their true character, as shams and impositions, and supplanted by true and legitimate governments, in the formation of which loyal men, black and white, shall participate.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">In the second article, published the following month, Douglass argued more specifically for <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1867/01/an-appeal-to-congress-for-impartial-suffrage/306547/?utm_source=feed">the voting rights of black Americans</a>, writing:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">The fundamental and unanswerable argument in favor of the enfranchisement of the negro is found in the undisputed fact of his manhood. He is a man, and by every fact and argument by which any man can sustain his right to vote, the negro can sustain his right equally. It is plain that, if the right belongs to any, it belongs to all. The doctrine that some men have no rights that others are bound to respect is a doctrine which we must banish, as we have banished slavery, from which it emanated. If black men have no rights in the eyes of white men, of course the white can have none in the eyes of the blacks. The result is a war of races, and the annihilation of all proper human relations.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">Though he is perhaps best remembered as an abolitionist and proponent of black equality, Douglass was also an outspoken and dedicated supporter of <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2015/04/frederick-douglass-defender-of-the-liberal-arts/389904/?utm_source=feed">education</a> and <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/personal/archive/2011/09/frederick-douglass-a-womens-rights-man/245977/?utm_source=feed">women’s rights</a>. It was this latter cause to which he dedicated his last day, attending sessions of the National Council of Women of the United States, and even his last moments, during which he spoke with his wife about the sessions.</p><p>As his <em>Times</em> obituary noted, “There is no end of stories about Mr. Douglass.” The distance he traveled in a lifetime is unfathomable: from an anonymous enslaved boy whose birthday no one thought to record to one of the most significant and respected figures of 19th-century America, whose death was marked with a detailed notice in the national news. The distance his memory has traveled since—into classrooms and legislative chambers, across oceans, from generation to generation to generation—is a testament to his extraordinary impact. Two hundred years after the date of his birth was unmarked and forgotten, his life and legacy remain remarkable; unforgettable.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/u1FItFIlVPA" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Annika Neklason</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/annika-neklason/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2018/02/3a18122v/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>George Francis Schreiber / Library of Congress</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">The Mystery Behind Frederick Douglass's Birthday</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/u1FItFIlVPA/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-17T08:00:00-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-17T08:51:55-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:50-553571</id><summary type="html">Two hundred years ago, one of the 19th century’s most significant Americans began his life in anonymity and bondage.</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2018/02/the-mystery-behind-frederick-douglasss-birthday/553571/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><iframe frameborder="no" height="200" scrolling="no" src="https://player.megaphone.fm/ATL6070844102?" width="100%"></iframe></p><p><small><i>Updated on February 16, 2018, at 1:53 p.m. ET</i></small></p><p><span>In 1987, Jeffrey Young was robbed and killed, and his body was left on a street in the poor neighborhood of West Dallas. Benjamine Spencer was tried and convicted for the attack.</span></p><p><span>Spencer was black, 22 years old, and recently married. Young was 33 and white, and his father was a senior executive for Ross Perot, one of the most prominent businessmen in Dallas. No physical evidence connected Spencer to the murder. Instead, he was convicted based on the testimony of three eyewitnesses and a jailhouse informant who claimed Spencer confessed to the crime. Spencer has now been in prison for most of his life.</span><span> </span></p><aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside><p><span>From behind bars, Spencer amassed evidence to support his claim of innocence, and secured the assistance of Centurion Ministries, a group that re-examines cases of prisoners like him. Together, they were able to convince a Texas judge of Spencer’s innocence. In investigating this story, not only did we confirm Centurion’s findings, but we’ve gathered new, exculpatory evidence, some of which appears first in this special, three-episode series of <em>Radio Atlantic</em>. </span></p><p dir="ltr">Despite the exculpatory evidence that has emerged since Spencer’s incarceration, he has few prospects for securing a new trial, or parole. Just after this story was published, on February 16, 2018, we received word that Spencer was again denied parole, as he has been every year since he became eligible. This comes as no surprise. The district attorney and the family of the victim both opposed his parole.</p><p dir="ltr">The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles offered two reasons for denial. First, the Board ruled that Spencer has repeatedly committed crimes and is predisposed to commit crimes in the future. Before being convicted for the robbery and murder of Jeffrey Young, Spencer had never been convicted of a violent crime. He had previously been convicted of driving with a suspended license and joyriding in a stolen car. Second, the Board found that the brutal nature of the crime made Spencer a continuing threat to public safety.</p><p>With this denial, Spencer finds the most plausible path to freedom blocked once again. The next time his case comes before the Texas Parole Board will be in February 2019. There’s little reason to think the Board will vote differently then, since the crime Spencer was convicted of will never change: Jeffrey Young will still have been beaten and killed that Sunday night in March 1987. Spencer’s best, narrow hope is that new evidence uncovered by <em>The Atlantic</em> might contain DNA that points to a different killer. Without that, Benjamine Spencer will wake up every day in a maximum security prison, with no way out.</p><p><strong>Key individuals mentioned in this story</strong> (listed in order of appearance):</p><ul><li><strong>Benjamine Spencer</strong>, the prisoner, convicted in October 1987<span>, retried and convicted in March 1988, given life in prison</span></li>

</ul><p><em><a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/podcasts/radio-atlantic/?utm_source=feed">Subscribe to Radio Atlantic</a> to hear part two in the “No Way Out” series when it's released.</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/u4h4D6nncmY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Barbara Bradley Hagerty </name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/barbara-bradley-hagerty/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2018/02/171101_TheAtlantic_BenSpencer_38/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Nathan Bajar / The Atlantic</media:credit></media:content><title type="html"><i>Radio Atlantic</i>: No Way Out, Part I</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/u4h4D6nncmY/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-16T00:00:00-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-16T16:23:27-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:50-553535</id><summary type="html">Benjamine Spencer has been in prison most of his life for a violent crime he may not have committed. But his guilt or innocence may no longer matter to the justice system.</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2018/02/radio-atlantic-no-way-out-part-i/553535/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>After a deadly shooting, the debate always, it seems, breaks down like this: One side argues for gun control, and the other argues there is no research proving those measures work. There is, in fact, <a href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2595514">little research into gun violence at all</a>—especially compared to other causes of death in the United States.</p><p>The modern origins of the impasse can be traced to 1996, when Congress passed an amendment to a spending bill that forbade the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention from using money to “advocate or promote gun control.”</p><p>The National Rifle Association had pushed for the amendment, after public-health researchers produced a spate of studies suggesting that, for example, having a gun in the house increased risk of homicide and suicide. It deemed the research politically motivated. Gun-rights advocates zeroed in on statements like that of Mark Rosenberg, then the director of the CDC’s National Center for Injury Prevention and Control. In response to the early ’90s crime wave, Rosenberg had <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/1994/10/16/us/new-tactics-urged-in-fight-against-crime.html">said in 1994</a>, “We need to revolutionize the way we look at guns, like what we did with cigarettes ... It used to be that smoking was a glamour symbol—cool, sexy, macho. Now it is dirty, deadly—and banned.”</p><p>The actual amendment sponsored by Jay Dickey, a congressman from Arkansas, did not explicitly forbid research into gun-related deaths, just advocacy. But the Congress also lowered the CDC’s budget by the exact amount it spent on such research. Message received. It’s had a chilling effect on the entire field for decades.</p><p>Medical and public-health professionals have been pushing back—more and more forcefully in recent years. The <a href="https://www.apha.org/topics-and-issues/gun-violence">American Public Health Association</a> and the <a href="https://www.ama-assn.org/ama-calls-gun-violence-public-health-crisis">American Medical Association</a> have both taken to calling gun violence a public-health problem. In 2016, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/06/cdc-congress-research-gun-violence-public-health">more than 100 medical organizations signed a letter </a>to Congress asking to lift the Dickey Amendment.</p><p>“We in public health count dead people. It’s one of the things we do. And we count them in order to understand how to prevent preventable deaths,” Nancy Krieger, an epidemiologist at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/12/08/458952821/congress-still-limits-health-research-on-gun-violence">told NPR</a> in 2015.</p><p>The CDC is best known for fighting diseases—it’s in the name—but its public-health purview is indeed wider. The agency studies drownings, accidental falls, traumatic brain injuries, car crashes, suicides, and more. And while mass shootings grab headlines, they account for only a small fraction of the 30,000 gun deaths a year in the United States. More than half are suicides. Yet the 1996 amendment has restricted how much the CDC can focus on gun ownership as the risk factor in suicides.</p><p>Researchers who do want to study gun violence have cobbled together funding from a patchwork of sources, often from private foundations. President Obama signed an executive order directing the National Institutes of Health to fund research into gun violence after the Sandy Hook shooting, but the <a href="https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/09/nih-quietly-shelves-gun-research-program">program has since petered out</a>.</p><aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside><p>The problem, researchers say, is also a lack of data. While motor-vehicle deaths are tracked in minute detail in the Fatality Analysis Reporting System, <a href="https://www.wired.com/2015/10/america-still-doesnt-good-data-guns/">no such comparable database exists for gun deaths</a>. Basic questions like exactly how many households own guns are not definitively answered.</p><p>Dickey, the congressman responsible for the amendment suppressing the CDC’s gun violence research, passed away last April. He had come to regret his role in the episode. In 2012, he coauthored a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/we-wont-know-the-cause-of-gun-violence-until-we-look-for-it/2012/07/27/gJQAPfenEX_story.html"><em>Washington Post </em>op-ed </a>with Rosenberg, the very CDC official he squared off against when passing the amendment. Together, they argued for more gun-violence research.</p><p>Dickey <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/US/federal-government-study-gun-violence/story?id=50300379">told reporters</a>, “I wish I had not been so reactionary.”</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/JHMkGMEouDs" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Sarah Zhang</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/sarah-zhang/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2018/02/AP_18046012297009/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Joe Skipper / AP </media:credit><media:description>Two doctors who treated victims of the Parkland school shooting at a press conference </media:description></media:content><title type="html">Why Can't the U.S. Treat Gun Violence as a Public-Health Problem? </title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/JHMkGMEouDs/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-15T12:21:13-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-15T18:27:50-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:50-553430</id><summary type="html">A 1996 bill has had a chilling effect on the CDC’s ability to research firearms.</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2018/02/gun-violence-public-health/553430/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>In his inaugural address, Donald Trump declared, “This American carnage stops right here and stops right now.” He knew it would not. We know it did not.</p><p>“I’ll be able to make sure that when you walk down the street in your inner city, or wherever you are, you’re not going to be shot,” he <a href="https://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trump-black-hispanic-voters-shot-227369">declared</a> during the campaign. “Your child isn’t going to be shot.” He has not been able to make sure of that––ask any parent whose children were caught up in any of the recent school shootings.</p><p>Trump gave those credulous enough to believe him false hope.</p><p>“The crime and violence that today afflicts our nation will soon come to an end,” he vowed at the Republican National Convention. “Beginning on January 20, 2017, safety will be restored.” But safety was not restored that day. Neither crime nor violence ended. The vow was a cynical ploy to get votes.</p><p>It worked.</p><p>And now, sadly but predictably, Trump has been proven wrong again. At least 17 people were killed in a mass shooting at a Florida high school. Children were killed.</p><p>Earlier in his tenure, a gunman in Las Vegas killed 58 and injured 851 in the deadliest mass shooting ever committed in the United States. Trump had no plan to stop such an attack, nor did he do anything after the fact that would prevent a similar attack. Such attacks are beyond anyone’s capacity to wholly eliminate, but no one else rose to power falsely promising they <em>could</em> stop such things.</p><p>Had Trump had a plan, had he attempted an innovative solution and failed, that would be forgivable—but he never had any viable strategy for keeping his promises.</p><p>And that he purported to be able to end carnage only to have so many slaughtered by a domestic terrorist––that he claimed he could stop children from being shot only to see multiple school shootings occur during his presidency––is a reality check for the country: None of his assurances can be counted upon.</p><p>His talent is bluffing, not delivering results.</p><p>This country needs to make alternative plans for American greatness, because the president who disingenuously promised to end carnage isn’t going to deliver elsewhere either. He won’t end the opiate crisis. He isn’t going to rebuild the country’s infrastructure. He makes lots of promises that he cannot possibly keep.</p><p>Often, he’s not even trying.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/YP-87GdCdNM" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Conor Friedersdorf</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/conor-friedersdorf/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2018/02/RTX4WX88-1/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>WSVN.com / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">American Carnage</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/YP-87GdCdNM/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-15T09:13:30-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-15T13:58:53-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:50-553424</id><summary type="html">“Your child isn’t going to be shot,” Donald Trump vowed. It was a promise he could never have kept—but there’s no evidence he even tried.</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/trump-carnage/553424/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>Could Amazon flip a state?</p><p>Amid all <a href="https://www.citylab.com/equity/2018/01/what-to-do-about-hq2/551486/">the public chatter over</a> the company’s search for a second North American headquarters, there’s been strikingly little discussion about the potential political impact. But the choice’s electoral implications could be substantial.</p><p>Just as Democrats are becoming increasingly reliant on younger, better-educated, and urbanized voters, Amazon’s second headquarters could bring tens of thousands of such workers to a state. That wouldn’t affect national politics much if Amazon picked one of the finalists from an already solidly blue state, such as New York City or Los Angeles. But if it chose a city from an existing or emerging battleground—its list of 20 finalists includes Columbus, Pittsburgh, Atlanta, and Raleigh—the addition of so many younger workers could provide an important thumb on the scale for Democrats.</p><aside class="callout-placeholder" data-source="curated"></aside><p>Amazon has signaled it intends to finalize its choice this year. Once it’s established, the number of workers connected to the new corporate hub is expected to grow significantly, with Amazon actively recruiting employees from around the country. Amazon projects that it will directly inject into the winning community up to 50,000 new jobs and $5 billion in investment. Based on the spin-off effects it has experienced in Seattle, the site of its first headquarters, Amazon forecasts that other companies will create roughly as many additional jobs. Add in the workers’ families, and Amazon’s choice city could attract well over 100,000 new residents.</p><p>That migration could have a long fuse before it changes a state’s balance of power. But there’s precedent for it: Many analysts consider the technology boom that flourished in Northern Virginia after Steve Case relocated the AOL headquarters there in the 1990s to be one of the factors that tipped the state toward the Democrats two decades later.</p><p>Those familiar with the process who I spoke with all say that in assessing the 19 finalists located in the United States, Amazon is not considering whether its choice will change a state’s partisan balance. (One of the finalists, Toronto, is located in Canada.) The criteria the company has listed emphasize such economic factors as a highly skilled workforce and reliable access to transportation. And yet an economic decision this large inexorably carries big political ramifications.</p><p>As a group, Amazon’s U.S. finalists are strongly Democratic-leaning. Echelon Insights, a Republican consulting firm that specializes in demographic change, <a href="https://medium.com/echelon-indicators/the-politics-of-amazons-hq2-search-ba106a9eece">recently calculated</a> that in the media markets that include the finalists, Hillary Clinton crushed President Trump by 57 percent to 38 percent in 2016. That result reflects the underlying demography of these communities: Compared with the other largest media markets that have no Amazon finalists, they have slightly more white college graduates and many more minority residents—with considerably fewer of the blue-collar whites that provided Trump’s core support.</p><p>But there are political gradations among the finalists. While Clinton probably won the downtown neighborhoods in all 19 communities, Trump carried the wider media market in five of them, noted Patrick Ruffini, Echelon’s co-founder: Dallas, Pittsburgh, Indianapolis, Columbus, and Nashville. The finalists represent economic gradations, too, with several of them offering much more developed technology ecosystems than the others.</p><p>“Is this going to be a choice that reinforces and further concentrates the winners in the new economy—some place on the coasts, or some place that is already very [highly] college-educated?” Ruffini asked. “Or are we going to see a major tech hub sprout potentially in a red state that may have political implications for how that state goes in the future?”</p><p>Ruffini’s questions underscore the intertwined nature of Amazon’s economic and political choices. Almost all of the finalists from the solidly blue states are places already thriving in the digital economy, such as New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston, Northern Virginia, and Denver. In choosing any of those, Amazon would be reinforcing economic and political dynamics that are already under way.</p><p>But many of the potential locations from swing <a href="https://www.brookings.edu/blog/the-avenue/2017/03/08/tech-in-metros-the-strong-are-getting-stronger/">states are smaller or more nascent technology centers</a>. That list includes Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Indianapolis, Columbus, Nashville, and Raleigh. In these places, Amazon could unambiguously function as a catalyst for economic transformation—a potentially attractive prospect. Even locating in one of the larger Sunbelt cities with a well-established tech scene—Austin, Dallas, and Atlanta are the strongest—might allow the company to argue it is more equitably distributing opportunity. That could assuage growing concerns that the digital economy is excessively benefiting only a handful of “superstar cities.”</p><p>In that way, Amazon’s own internal political needs could encourage it to pick one of the options beyond the established big-blue tech centers—precisely the kind of selection that could also trigger the broadest electoral impact. The competing consideration is that the company’s need to recruit large numbers of young workers could make it reluctant to pick even a blue-leaning city in a red state. Like other tech companies, it might fear that state-level politics—say, the potential passage of a “bathroom bill” or hardline immigration policies—would discourage those recruits.</p><p>The states on the finalist roster aren’t all equally susceptible to tipping. Even this big an infusion of blue-leaning tech workers might not have much impact in a state the size of Texas or Florida. And it would be unlikely to overcome the overall advantages Republicans have established in Indiana and Tennessee, and are solidifying in Ohio.</p><p>But the company’s selection could plausibly nudge the current swing states of Pennsylvania and North Carolina toward the Democrats—or accelerate Georgia’s transition into a genuinely competitive battleground. It might take years, but if Amazon founder Jeff Bezos picks one of those places, he could deliver a major political disruption right to the two parties’ doorsteps.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/hdT3V7NZUOM" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Ronald Brownstein</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/ronald-brownstein/?utm_source=feed</uri></author><media:content url="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2018/02/AP_18040786053647/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Rich Pedroncelli / AP</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">Could Amazon Flip a State?</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/hdT3V7NZUOM/" rel="alternate" /><published>2018-02-15T05:00:00-05:00</published><updated>2018-02-15T13:59:14-05:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2018:50-553394</id><summary type="html">Democrats could gain politically if the company chooses a city in a battleground state for its second North American headquarters.</summary><feedburner:origLink>https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/amazon-headquarters-politics/553394/?utm_source=feed</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><iframe width="640" height="360" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" src="https://www.theatlantic.com/video/iframe/553298/"></iframe>
<p dir="ltr">“The Trump Republican party shames itself every day,” argues <em>The Atlantic</em> writer and David Frum. “Some people think we’d be better off if the GOP just went out of business. That’s dangerous advice.”</p>

After all, “it’s not a coincidence that Breitbart.com was founded by Californians,” says Frum.</p>
